docs.lead_paragraph: SECTOR funds, which concentrate their holdings in particular industries, are notoriously volatile. Investing in one can result in a home run or a strikeout. This is not surprising. After all, if diversifying stock portfolios can iron out their volatility, then narrowing their focus to single industries will increase it. And the losses can be big. Last year, for instance, the Fidelity Precious Metals and Minerals fund plunged 44.9 percent.

headline.main: Avoiding Some Bumps Along the Sector Road

docs.abstract: Article on continuing volatility of sector mutual funds, which concentrate holdings in particular industries; photo (Money & Business Part 2: Mutual Funds Report) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Some people play favorites with the Bill of Rights. The favorite amendment of gangsters is the fifth (no self-incrimination), of liberals the first (free speech), of drug dealers the fourth (no unauthorized search), of gun fondlers the second (to bear arms). Now, many people have a new favorite, the long-neglected 10th (powers not specifically assigned to Washington are reserved to the states). As recently as 1985, when the Supreme Court reversed one of its rare decisions based on the amendment (Garcia canceling Usery), the 10th was being called a dead letter. Certainly few people tried to ''take the 10th'' the way gangsters and fellow travelers ''took the fifth.'' But now the amendment has many takers. The Supreme Court used it in 1992, 1995 and 1997 and shows an eagerness to extend that run. Bob Dole, in his last year in the Senate, began carrying the words of the amendment around with him for instant recitation. Newt Gingrich's insurgents relied on it in 1994 to preach devolution of power from the Federal to the state level. Even President Clinton gives states the title Louis Brandeis thought up for them, ''laboratories of democracy.'' Gov. Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin thinks it is high time for the amendment to be resurrected. He claims he has been a voice for the 10th crying in the wilderness for many years.

headline.main: The War Between the States ... and Washington

docs.abstract: Garry Wills article on key role being played by states in starting, altering and killing social programs; states have been out ahead of Federal programs on range of issues, reversing long-term trend; people with new ideas and passion for public policy are turning away from Federal Government and attacking social issues at state and local levels; much of activity has been spurred or guided by new generation of Republican governors, whose careers depend on making programs work; Wisconsin's centrally planned innovations, led by Gov Tommy Thompson, contrast with mixed bag of changes enacted by California voters through popular initiatives; drawings (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A40-YEAR-OLD woman struggling to conceive a baby is told by her doctor that the quality of her eggs is poor and the lining of her uterus doesn't replenish itself well enough to sustain a pregnancy. Is she fairly average, or is she disabled? The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 last month that reproduction was a ''major life activity'' and that when a person's ability to reproduce is substantially limited she (or he) meets the definition of disability under the Americans With Disabilities Act.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends: Defining Disability; AIDS Virus Case Opens Door for Infertile

docs.abstract: Supreme Court ruling that reproduction is 'major life activity' discussed as to implication that the infertile may now claim rights under disability law; actual case involved suit against dentist who refused to treat woman infected with AIDS virus; Court ruled she qualifies for protection because, although not infertile, she decided not to have children for fear of passing on virus; decision may prod employers to give workers more time for infertility treatments; insurance coverage may also be affected (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Susan Rochelle Kramer, a daughter of Esther and Stuart Kramer of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married last evening to Christophe Patrick Guillemot, a son of Marie-France and Pierre Guillemot of Chateau-Thierry, France. Rabbi Paul Levinson officiated at the house of the bride's parents in Wellfleet, Mass. Ms. Kramer, 33, is a screenwriter in New York. She graduated from the University of California at Los Angeles. Her father, an electrical engineer, retired from Lucent Technologies in Whippany, N.J., as a Bell Labs Fellow; he is now a distinguished member of the technical staff at General Dynamics, in Whippany. Her mother is a logistics analyst at American Home Products, the health-care products company in Parsippany, N.J.

docs.lead_paragraph: As lawmakers in Washington prepare for a legislative duel over managed care, the issue has begun to shake up a number of political races across the country, none more so than the Senate challenge here between a millionaire lawyer and a conservative incumbent. Back when few candidates were talking about it, John Edwards, the Democrat who is challenging Senator Lauch Faircloth in one of the year's tightest races, noticed that people got sputtering mad almost every time he mentioned managed care. He hasn't stopped talking about it since.
docs.abstract: Managed care becomes central issue in Senate race in North Carolina; John Edwards, Democrat seeking to unseat Lauch Faircloth, says insurance industry is fleecing patients; favors legislation to make it easier for people to sue their HMO's for improper denial fo benefits; Faircloth, conservative Republican who is best known for his ties with business community, makes much the fact that Edwards is a millionaire personal-injury lawyer; special interests groups weigh in on both sides; photo (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: If Democrats and Republicans want to compromise on legislation to define patients' rights, they will have to bridge a broad conceptual and political gap. The Democrats would establish far more protections for consumers. But to do so, they would create vast new authority for the Federal Government to regulate the operation of health maintenance organizations and insurance companies. The Government would, for example, set standards for the quality of care, including coverage of prescription drugs and the length of hospital stays for mastectomy patients.

headline.main: 2 Patients' Rights Bills Take Divergent Roads

docs.abstract: Democrats and Republicans face broad conceptual and political gap on legislation to define patients' rights; Democatrats would establish far more protections for consumers, but by doing so would create vast new authority for Federal Government to regulate operation of health maintenance organizations and insurance companies; Republicans, wanting to trust the market and limit Government intervention, would expand use of medical savings accounts, limit damage awards in medical malpractice suits, and help small businesses band together to buy health insurance; both share common core that would require coverage of emergency care, establish appeals process, ban restrictions on what doctors can tell their patients about treatment options, and require health plans to disclose benefits, cost and performance information (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Clinton, at Beijing University, Presses Call for Liberty'' (front page, June 29): While it is appropriate to castigate China for accepting only those human rights that suit its own interests, President Clinton must recognize that even the United States continues to spurn rights guaranteed by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights -- economic and social rights that insure an adequate standard of living. It is not coincidental that the only industrialized country to reject economic and social rights also boasts the highest disparity between rich and poor and the highest child poverty rates among the industrialized countries.
docs.abstract: Letter by Anaradha Mittal, policy director of Institute for Food and Development Policy, says Pres Clinton, while appropriately attacking China's human rights record, must also recognize that rampant poverty in United States is another kind of human rights violation (June 29 article) (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your July 2 editorial on the demonstration against the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's awarding of a contract to a nonunion bidder focused on the small number of construction workers who turned violent. But the vast majority were orderly.

headline.main: Ask the Jobless If Marx Is Relevant

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc. agreed today to pay $100 million for a 75 percent stake in the Chilean health insurer Cruz Blanca Isapre S.A., the country's third-largest insurer. The purchase by Aetna, the largest United States health insurance company, would create a company with about 319,000 customers, or 18.6 percent of Chile's private health insurance market, according to an industry association. Aetna already operates an insurer in Chile.

headline.main: Aetna to Expand In Chilean Deal

docs.abstract: Aetna Inc agrees to pay $100 million for 75 percent stake in Chilean health insurer Cruz Blanca Isapre SA, country's third-largest insurer; purchase by Aetna, largest United States health insurance company, would create company with about 319,000 customers, or 18.6 percent of Chile's private health insurance market; Chile has one of best-developed health insurance markets in Latin America because by law companies are required to set aside part of every employee's salary for private insurance (S)
